User Experience¶

Stats functions adapted to the conventions of Freedman, Pisani, and Purves 2007.

class statwrap.ux.DataUploadWidget(variable_name, accept: str = '.csv,.xls,.xlsx,.xlsm,.xlsb,.odf,.ods,.odt', auto_display: bool = True)¶

A widget for uploading data files and creating a pandas DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • variable_name (str) – The name of the variable to store the DataFrame in the IPython environment.

  • accept (str, optional) – Accepted file extensions, default is ‘.csv,.xls,.xlsx,.xlsm,.xlsb,.odf,.ods,.odt’.

  • auto_display (bool, optional) – If True, the widget is displayed immediately upon creation. Default is True.

accept¶

Accepted file extensions.

Type:

str

supported¶

Supported file extensions.

Type:

set

uploader¶

File upload widget.

Type:

ipywidgets.FileUpload

submit_button¶

Button to create the DataFrame from the uploaded file.

Type:

ipywidgets.Button

variable_name¶

Name of the variable to store the DataFrame.

Type:

str

auto_display¶

If True, the widget is displayed immediately upon creation.

Type:

bool

createDF()¶

Creates a pandas DataFrame from the uploaded file.

uploadData()¶

Displays the file upload widget and button, and handles the file upload event.

Examples

Single DataFrame Usage: >>> uploader = DataUploadWidget(“df”)

Multiple DataFrame Usage: >>> uploader1 = DataUploadWidget(“df1”) >>> uploader2 = DataUploadWidget(“df2”)

Delayed Output Usage: >>> output = widgets.Output() >>> with output: >>> uploader = DataUploadWidget(‘df3’, auto_display=False) >>> display(output) >>> display(uploader.uploader, uploader.submit_button)

createDF()¶

Create a pandas DataFrame from the uploaded file.

Returns:

DataFrame created from the uploaded file.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

ValueError – If the file extension is unsupported.

uploadData()¶

Display the file upload widget and button, and handle the file upload event.
